signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-title: SignalsLink - extension of the Signals mod
signalslink:block-handbooktext-blocksens:
The block sensor detects the presence of a block at the selected adjacent position and, based on its type or an input signal, provides output information about its state or slot fill level.
Currently supported blocks are:
Anvil - if there is a sufficiently hot ingot on the anvil ready for forging, the Output signal is 1. Otherwise it sends signal 0.
Doors, gates, trapdoors - For doors and gates you need to monitor the ground-level block on the hinge side. If the block is open, the Output signal is 1; if it is closed, the Output signal is 0.
Chest or generally a container or any blocks that have inventory slots (e.g., firepit, barrel, trough, etc.). The Output signal depends on the input signal.
The input signal determines which slot should be scanned.
Signal 1-14 selects slots 0-13. The output is information about how full the slot is relative to the maximum stack capacity of the item in that slot, converted to a 0-15 signal.
Signal 15 means the sensor should detect the total fill level of all slots, e.g. the whole chest.
Some other block not listed above - If there is nothing in the monitored space (air), the Output signal is 0. If there is water, the output is 2 for fresh water or 3 for salt water. If there is any other block, the Output signal is 1.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-entitysen:
The entity sensor detects the presence of entities (players, livestock, wild animals, or monsters) within the marked area and can provide information on its outputs about their count, type, or state. To operate, the sensor requires charging with one or more Temporal gears. The consumption rate then depends on the size of the monitored area.
Inputs x, y, z determine the size of the monitored area in blocks.
On the Error output there is signal 1 if the sensor is out of charge, otherwise 0.
Inputs Output setting 1 and Output setting 2 determine what information will be provided on outputs 1 and 2. This way you can get different information on each output based on these input settings.
Options are:
1 - The output returns Count. The number of detected entities.
2 - The output returns Category. Bit flags for entity categories 0–3: player, creature, animal, wild animal.
3 - The output returns Life state. All detected entities are: 1–dead, 2–alive, or 15–mixed.
4 - The output returns Gender. All detected entities are: 1–male, 2–female, or 15–mixed.
5 - The output returns Age. All detected entities are: 1–young, 2–adult, or 15–mixed.
6 - The output returns Species. All detected entities are: 1–player, 2–animal, 3–wild animal, 4–creature, or 15–mixed.
7 - The output returns Reproductive state. All detected entities are: 1–ready to mate, 2–pregnant, 3–lactating, or 15–mixed.
8 - The output returns Reproductive state flags. Bit flags 0–2: ready to mate, pregnant, lactating.
9 - The output returns Minimum generation. The minimum detected generation is: 0–15. Present entities without a specified generation are ignored.
10 - The output returns Maximum generation. The maximum detected generation is: 0–15. Present entities without a specified generation are ignored.
11 - The output returns Minimum weight. The minimum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Present entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
12 - The output returns Maximum weight. The maximum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Present entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedch: The managed chute enables automated transport of items between different blocks.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedwa: A managed chute embedded in a wall enables automated transport of items between different blocks. It allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for moving items from a cellar or into a cellar without disturbing the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food storage.
signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-text:
SignalsLink
Extends the Signals mod with additional components.

To monitor a nearby block you can use the Block sensor.
If you need to monitor your herd of livestock, the Entity sensor is great for that.
If you want to automate certain tasks, the Managed chute will serve you well; it can transport items between blocks similarly to a chute, but you control it with signals and it gives you much greater control over what gets transported. Its variant, the Managed chute built into a wall, then allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for moving items from a cellar or into a cellar without disturbing the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food storage.
signalslink:usageinfo-paperconditions-te:
Some blocks from the SignalsLink mod allow using paper conditions:
• Block sensor
• Managed chute
• Managed chute built into a wall
Paper conditionspaper conditions are conditions written on parchment. These conditions can be used to influence a block’s behavior, for example to control output signals or to filter items in chutes.
Conditions are written into blocks (paragraphs). Each block consists of one or more lines, where each line contains one condition. All conditions within one block are evaluated by applying the logical AND operator between them, and the result yields the resulting value of the whole block.
Individual blocks are separated by an empty line. The resulting values of the individual blocks then have the logical OR operator applied. Evaluation of individual conditions within a block proceeds from top to bottom as they are listed on the paper. Evaluation of blocks also proceeds in the order in which the blocks are listed on the paper. This means that as soon as a block evaluates to true, this result is returned to the calling block and no further blocks are processed. This is very important and must be taken into account.

We distinguish several types of conditions:
game:plank-oak - Evaluates whether the tracked item in the inventory or the tracked block is of the specified type, i.e. its code matches exactly the specified code. If yes, the condition returns true.
game:plank-* - Evaluates whether the tracked item or block is of the specified type in any of its variants (marked with an asterisk). If yes, the condition returns true.
@.*-plank-.* - The code of the tracked item or block is evaluated using this regular expression. If it matches, the condition returns true.
attribute > 1 - Evaluates the value of an attribute of the item in the inventory or the tracked block. Various comparison operators (greater/less/equal) can be used. After evaluation, the comparison result (true/false) is returned.
attribute - If only the attribute name is given in the condition, it evaluates whether it has a value or not. That is, zero, NULL, an empty string, or false evaluates as false. A non-zero value, a string, or true evaluates as true.

The negation operator ! can be applied to all conditions. For example, !game:plank-oak evaluates as true if the tracked item or block is not exactly oak planks.
At the end of each block you can add an instruction to set the output signal, for example output 1, which specifies that if this block evaluates to true, signal 1 will be sent to the output. This is only meaningful for the Block sensor, which allows you to set what signal will be sent to the output if a block or item matches the conditions listed in the block. For the other blocks that allow using paper conditions, this instruction is ignored.Setting up conditionsWrite the conditions on parchment. Do not sign the parchment so that you can edit the text again.
Transfer the conditions into a block that supports it by right-clicking that block with this parchment. The conditions will be saved into the block and you will see them in the info window when you look at the block.
To remove conditions from a block, hold a blank parchment, crouch (shift key), and right-click the block with the blank parchment. This deletes the conditions from the block.
If you want to copy conditions from a block onto a blank parchment, right-click the block with a blank parchment without crouching.
And finally, a tip for finding out what code a block or item has and what attributes you have available for use in conditional expressions:
Hold the item you are interested in, hold the ctrl key, and right-click this item on a block that supports paper conditions. The item code and its attributes available for paper conditions will be saved into that block. You can now copy them onto a blank parchment as described above, and here you can freely edit them into condition blocks and use them to configure the block.
